column1: The health care provider uses a dipstick made with a color-sensitive pad.
Your provider will ask you to temporarily stop taking any medicines that may affect the test results.

Increased urine specific gravity may be due to conditions such as: - Loss of body fluids (dehydration) - Diarrhea that causes dehydration - Heart failure - Sugar (glucose) in the urine - Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) Decreased urine specific gravity may be due to: - Damage to kidney tubule cells (renal tubular necrosis) - Diabetes insipidus - Drinking too much fluid - Kidney failure
